results.title: Expo 67 explore!
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Crawley Films and Vincent Vaitiekunas
results.brief_description: Anyone bent on really remembering happy days at Montreal’s world’s fair, Expo 67, is likely to agree that this film is it. In a brief quarter-hour it explores most of the fair at a friendly, unhurried pace, with many a pause to smile and enjoy. It will please anyone who saw Expo, and even more, those who missed the opportunity to be there themselves. No dialogue, musical background only.

results.title: Exploring, investigating, learning (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Presents sequences of children playing in a kindergarten program and explains the role teachers may take. It is about exploring, about young children’s investigating behaviour and ways of helping children to take an active role in their own development.

results.title: Exploring your growth
results.creator_credit: Churchill-Wexler Film Productions and Heath Elementary Science
results.brief_description: Uses simple animation and photomicrography to explore the process that makes a person grow. Explains how food is digested in the mouth, stomach, and intestine; how the digested food is carried by the blood from the intestine to the cells of the body; and how food allows cells to grow and divide, causing growth.

results.title: Exploring the unwritten past
results.brief_description: A description of scientific investigation into the past, and modern techniques in archaeology. Shows how the fascinating story of man in Britain, covering the earliest discovery of the great antiquity of mankind in Kent’s Cavern in Devon to the decorative arts of the Celtic Iron age and the coming of the Romans, is being unravelled by experts. Illustrates the changing way of life through outstanding sites and monuments, together with objects which have played a part in piecing together the story.

results.title: Exploring the universe
results.creator_credit: Walter Bartky and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the principle and construction of telescopes. Shows by animation the binaries, trinaries, the variables and why they vary, galaxies and galactic rotation. Shows also what will happen to the Big Dipper in 100,000 years and illustrates the theory of the expanding universe.

Shows also what will happen to the Big Dipper in 100,000 years and illustrates the theory of the expanding universe.

results.title: Exploring the ocean. - Rev. ed.
results.brief_description: Discusses the ocean floor, plants, animals and the food chain, the ocean’s storehouse of minerals and how they are deposited by the water cycle, and pollution in the ocean.

results.title: Exploring the ocean
results.brief_description: Points out that although we have charted the ocean’s surface in detail, below the surface lies a part of the world that we are just beginning to explore. Uses animation to picture the ocean’s floor, slopes and continental shelves, and to explain how we explore by sounding and photography. Describes the ocean’s plants and animals and explains how all life in the ocean depends on the tiniest forms of plant life. Discusses the ocean’s vast storehouse of minerals and describes the part played by the water cycle in depositing these minerals.

results.title: Exploring the night sky
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A class-room film explaining the nature of stars and constellations and demonstrating the operation of an observatory telescope. Uses animation to identify the characters and shapes associated with constellations, explaining why they appear to be changing positions in the sky. Points out that the distances between stars and planets is not expressed in miles but light years.

results.title: Exploring the human nervous system
results.brief_description: The advances being made in research into the workings of the human nervous system. The nervous system itself is described by means of animated drawings. Also indicates what is being done to understand memory and learning. Compares the nervous systems of the hydra and the earth worm with the complex human nervous system.
